perturbation.original_text: THIS SECOND AMENDMENT TO CO-BRANDING AGREEMENT (this "Amendment") is made and entered into, effective for all purposes and in all respects as of the 23rd day of February, 1998, by and between PC QUOTE, INC., with its principal place of business at 300 South Wacker Drive, Chicago, Illinois 60605 ("PCQ") and A.B. Watley, Inc., with its principal place of business at 33 West 17th Street, New York, New York 10011 ("ABW").
perturbation.changed_text: THIS SECOND AMENDMENT TO CO-BRANDING AGREEMENT (this "Amendment") is made and entered into, effective for all purposes and in all respects as of the 23rd day of February, 1998, by and between PC QUOTE, INC., with its principal place of business and A.B. Watley, Inc., with its principal place of business.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the addresses of both companies, the contract becomes vague and potentially unenforceable. Under contract law, specifically in Illinois and New York (the states where the companies are located), clear identification of the parties involved, including their principal places of business, is important for establishing jurisdiction and ensuring proper notification. Omitting this information introduces ambiguity, creating a potential loophole that could be exploited to challenge the contract's validity.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract Law - Essential Elements of a Contract (Illinois and New York)

perturbation.original_text: WHEREAS, PCQ and ABW have executed that certain Co-Branding Agreement dated October 11, 1996, as amended on December 10, 1996 (as so amended, the "Agreement");
perturbation.changed_text: WHEREAS, PCQ and ABW have executed a Co-Branding Agreement;
perturbation.explanation: Removing the specific dates of the original agreement and its first amendment creates ambiguity about which version of the co-branding agreement this second amendment applies to. This could lead to disputes about which terms are currently in effect. Contract law requires clarity and specificity in identifying the documents being amended. The omission of specific dates makes it difficult to determine the precise obligations of each party and could render the amendment unenforceable.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract Law - Requirement for Definiteness and Certainty

perturbation.original_text: NOW, THEREFORE, in consideration of the foregoing, of the mutual promises for the parties contained herein and of other good valuable consideration, the receipt and sufficiency of which are hereby acknowledged, the parties hereto, intending legally to be bound, hereby covenant and agree as follows:
perturbation.changed_text: NOW, THEREFORE, in consideration of the foregoing, of the mutual promises for the parties contained herein, the parties hereto covenant and agree as follows:
perturbation.explanation: Removing the phrase 'and of other good valuable consideration, the receipt and sufficiency of which are hereby acknowledged' weakens the statement of consideration. Consideration is a crucial element for a contract to be legally binding. While mutual promises are stated, explicitly acknowledging the receipt and sufficiency of 'other good valuable consideration' provides additional assurance that the agreement is supported by adequate value exchange. Its omission can provide grounds to challenge the enforceability of the contract, arguing a lack of sufficient consideration.
